fastcopywriter:
I read that in New Jersey a family got arrested for inviting more than 50 people to a wedding at home.
4 members of the same family died (of corona) in New Jersey after attending a large family gathering.
fastcopywriter:
People your age are unlikely to catch covid.
A 25-year-old nurse in Italy died of covid.
Yes, at your age (and mine, I‚Äôll be 44 too, in November), you‚Äôre less likely to die of it if you catch it, but you can infect others who are more vulnerable.
The trouble is that people are undisciplined. Self-isolation wouldn‚Äôt be necessary if everyone remembered to stay 2 meters away from everyone else. But the other day in the supermarket, a woman who was dutifully wearing a mask tried to stand so close behind me she was practically breathing down my neck (and no, it wasn‚Äôt for the lack of space, there was plenty of room behind her).

reply_text:
maedan:
Yes, in my opinion. Human life and health has no price. Economy will take a hit, eventually recover, but some people that catch this virus will unfortunately not share the same fate.
And yet Italy is denying respirators to people over 60. See? Human life has a price, and when the government controls your healthcare, they decide who lives and who dies, who‚Äôs valuable and who has been alive too long for them to care.
misscrystal:
No one has immunity to this disease and it‚Äôs impossible to determine who will be able to throw it off like a case of the flu, and who will become more sick.
My point is not everyone is susceptible to this disease, not everyone catches it. Right now Home Depot (and other retailers I assume) instituted a rule where the store can‚Äôt have more than 100 people inside, including employees. So you can imagine the long lines of people waiting to get in. Ironically, there‚Äôs not much social isolation when you‚Äôre standing in line, so the measures are futile.
I do hope remdesivir works, I can‚Äôt wait to go back to normal. I hope we never again shut down society over a disease.
blavaro:
It is pity that in our country people still think so selfish these days.
Selfishness is the natural state of people. Altruism and self-sacrifice are aberrations. When someone orders for me, it‚Äôs for selfish reasons, same reason I serve my customers well. Altruism would require me to refund every order and tell my client, ‚ÄúI love you so much, that I want to work for you for free.‚Äù That I‚Äôll never do, I might give my clients extras to keep him coming back, see? Selfish reasons, but I wont‚Äô sacrifice my time and my money for anyone. If anyone gets a refund, that person is blocked and reported to Fiverr.
catwriter:
But the other day in the supermarket, a woman who was dutifully wearing a mask tried to stand so close behind me she was practically breathing down my neck (and no, it wasn‚Äôt for the lack of space, there was plenty of room behind her).
Today a customer at Home Depot tried to shake my hand, I declined politely. I see lots of people fist bumping, and one person elbow bumping which I suppose it‚Äôs safe. Some customers also get very close to me when they have a question. Staying 2 meters away from people is unrealistic. Countries should focus on finding a cure.

catwriter:
Because they don‚Äôt have enough ventilators for all the patients who need them, so they‚Äôre choosing the ones who have the better chance to survive.
That‚Äôs not right. That‚Äôs like waiting two years for a kidney, undergoing dialysis three times a week, and when a kidney is finally available, they give it to a celebrity.
If I show up to the hospital first, I‚Äôm supposed to be treated first. What kind of sickos choose who gets to live and who gets to die? If someone dies because all respirators were taken, that‚Äôs sad, but at least that person didn‚Äôt die because someone deemed him or her unworthy.
Older people are worthy. They have families, they‚Äôve paid taxes their entire lives, some of them fought in WW2, they should be honored instead of being sentenced to death by giving that respirator to another patient.
Anyway, that‚Äôs my opinion, we can agree to disagree.

Companies should embrace remote work permanently.
When they do that, they might as well embrace hiring freelancers instead of employees. Then it will become a case of companies constantly looking to reduce wage bills by hiring offshore workers.
Then there is the cybersecurity side of things. Then there is the slight problem that when you work from home you degenerate into an overweight blob that lives in less and less underwear every day and panics every time the doorbell rings‚Ä¶
Personally, I‚Äôve regretted freelancing for quite a few years now, as I miss the sociability side of things. However, I did tell everyone who thought I was mad when I left my last company, that within 5-years the economy would collapse and they would all be on benefits‚Ä¶ And although I was 3-years off, that has now happened‚Ä¶

reply_text:
This initial post was put up on Feb 27th. At that point, no one knew how this would fully play out in the US where I live. Nor did we really know how it would affect the rest of the world or Gig economy workers. Sitting here on March 25th, Sh&T got real! More than 1/3 of the US population is under stay at home orders. It does not mean that everyone is listening. NY is the epicenter of this in the US for now, cases and deaths are rising at record rates each day countrywide - but mainly NY. A sign of things to come in other states is what many seem to wonder. We are still, although better at testing, need more tests to get a read on the entire picture and testing is backlogged, so I do not believe we have the full picture of how this is spreading in places outside of the major epicenters here.
The daily briefings by Governers, especially Cuomo of NY, and that of our commander in Chief are fascinating and taking the place of sporting events I would be watching for entertainment. I will leave that alone for now.
Good news for self-employed Gig workers who are affected by this. Sounds. like they can file for unemployment and get that plus some via this new bailout bill from congress.
The school system I work in just announced closure for 4 more weeks with remote learning. It should be interesting to see how they implement that.
Amazing how things change in just one short month. It went from we are scared and watching and maybe it won‚Äôt be so bad to oh Sh&t!
Stay safe

@silberma1976 Thanks for the heads up on gig worker unemployment benefits:
Gig workers, freelancers, self-employed are eligible
In an unprecedented move, the stimulus bill expands unemployment protections to gig workers, freelancers and self-employed individuals, who typically don‚Äôt qualify for unemployment benefits.
Seth Harris, former Deputy U.S. Secretary of Labor, describes this aspect of the stimulus package as a ‚Äúgigantic change,‚Äù but notes that it could be complicated to execute.
‚ÄúIt will be harder [to calculate] because these workers don‚Äôt have a W-2 or an average weekly wage,‚Äù Harris says. ‚ÄúThese folks have income that varies dramatically from week to week or month to month.‚Äù
It‚Äôs not clear yet how state benefits will be calculated for these workers (from forbes)

We are in for a bumpy ride fellas

Hey. I believe that the situation with coronavirus should be viewed from an angle. And benefit from it. Many people are drowning in the routine of everyday life. Sleep, eat, go to work, watch a movie and sleep again. Now there is time to develop your skills. Time to give life to your ideas.
Therefore, I urge everyone not to lose heart. And start doing things and projects for which you did not have time. Now nothing distracts you. You can completely immerse yourself in creativity.
Have a nice day friends!

reply_text:
nikavoice:
Now, as far as the Sims 4 goes do you recommend it and why? Try to convince me to play hehehe.
Yes, I definitely recommend it. Why? Because you can control the lives, adventures, careers, families, and stories of digital sims. Your sims can interact with vampires, learn magic, become a college student, have pets, raise children, travel to another planet, and much more. Plus, you can build just about any kind of building, fill it with a wide assortment of furniture and possessions, reshape entire neighborhoods, kill your sim, bring them back to life, visit ancient places‚Ä¶ the list goes on.
I especially enjoy the extensive ‚Äúcreate-a-sim‚Äù feature. It has been a wonderful distraction to the challenges of a hard day. Or, just a great way to have fun and lose track of time.
The possibilities are endless.

Personally, I‚Äôm in the SF Bay Area and we‚Äôre on FULL ‚Äúshelter in place 45‚Äù orders. I‚Äôm working from home now with three kids (all under 6) so ‚Äúwork time‚Äù has gotten a lot crazier (only so many times I can hear my daughter sing ‚ÄúLET IT GOOOOO 37‚Äù).
Even if there is nothing that the community can do to help (resources, questions, shared experience), I‚Äôd love to hear how your work habits have changed in the last few weeks!
reply_text:
Our area of the state (my city, in fact) has had no OFFICIAL cases of COVID-19 but school is shut down, lots of the fun places are shut down. City businesses are operating on skeleton crews. The school districts‚Äô kitchen - my school district specifically - is feeding our children and community.
I talked with our school resource officer today, and he suspects we won‚Äôt be going back until May if at all (perhaps following the Kansas governor and shutting down for the rest of the school year).
With little work from Fiverr, I‚Äôm just taking a break and enjoying the downtime. It‚Äôs a rarity to not work when I‚Äôm not at the full-time job, so I‚Äôm enjoying this as much as I can. No gym, no fun things to do, cooped in the house. I‚Äôll make do.
Cook, clean, spend time with the boys and don‚Äôt get sick. That‚Äôs how I‚Äôm spending my time.

Personally, I‚Äôm in the SF Bay Area and we‚Äôre on FULL ‚Äúshelter in place 45‚Äù orders. I‚Äôm working from home now with three kids (all under 6) so ‚Äúwork time‚Äù has gotten a lot crazier (only so many times I can hear my daughter sing ‚ÄúLET IT GOOOOO 37‚Äù).
Even if there is nothing that the community can do to help (resources, questions, shared experience), I‚Äôd love to hear how your work habits have changed in the last few weeks!
reply_text:
Same ole for me. Self isolating, avoiding the outside world best I can. Stocked up pretty well but just carrying on with work here. My cat and I are quite comfortable.
The biggest ‚Äúconcern‚Äù I‚Äôve had with my Fiverr orders right now is the prospect of cancellation requests popping up.
Money may have changed for some people / businesses. What was once a priority is perhaps not so much right now whilst this thing goes on.
I have this uncertainty about orders in my queue - Will I get a message from a customer out of no where asking to cancel because of their money woes or because the business side of things is on hold? Will I get several? Should I jump on the orders sooner rather than later or chill out a bit‚Ä¶
It creates a bit of unease for me, doubly so because of the way Fiverr handles cancellations now and obviously because income for a lot of freelancers is volatile currently (more than normal).
Not sure if others are feeling it.

Doing okay myself, I‚Äôm not big on socializing in the first place, my main chance to get infected/infect is using public transport, which I avoid as far as possible now, of course. Spending as much time as possible in the park around the corner, and the fields/forest area a bit further away, as I can avoid contact there and on the way there as well and want to ‚Äúload up on being outside‚Äù before we may have curfew, and because it‚Äôs spring and beautiful, of course. A bit worried about a parent who‚Äôs in the highest risk group, and of course for everyone and everything, but not too much, as it won‚Äôt help anybody or anything.
Take care of yourselves, your loved ones and everyone else, and stay strong.

Hello fellow fiverians, first of all stay safe and healthy.
Situation in my country ‚ÄúMalaysia‚Äù has gone from bad to worst. Whole country is under lockdown, no one is allowed to go out and all private companies besides necessities are forced to shut down.

As far as work goes, everything still remains the same for now. Stay safe everyone and we hope this will end soon.

misscrystal:
I have a lovely tiny sidewalk cafe nearby I miss too.
I have a favorite small pizza place and I legitimately cried about it closing at my therapy session yesterday. Well, I think it was more about this feeling of the normalcy of life slowly slipping away, but yeah. I miss it and I‚Äôm worried that being such a small place, they won‚Äôt survive the economical repercussions.
Onto the fun stuff: the subway was closed, now if you can‚Äôt work from home, you have to use buses or cars. There can‚Äôt be more than 10 people on a bus at any given time. Which is a genius plan except I live in a city of 5+ million people with a huge river in the middle and very few bridges across. Angry mobs are storming buses, no one can really enforce the 10 people rule.
Our mayor is Vitaly Klitschko, a former world boxing champion, and I‚Äôm a bit horrified of his future brilliant initiatives.

Some people think ‚Äúthat won‚Äôt happen to me‚Äù and somehow feel it‚Äôs only for other people.
There is no way to avoid coming into contact with it for everyone in the world at some point in time. What we are trying to do is
‚Äúflatten the curve‚Äù so everyone does not get it all at once.
Some get it now and some can get it later on so hospitals and society won‚Äôt be so overwhelmed.
nytimes.com 1
Which Country Has Flattened the Curve for the Coronavirus? 1
These charts show the trajectory of the coronavirus pandemic in each country. New cases have dwindled in China and South Korea, but the virus continues to spread rapidly in most of the world.
Some may never get it if that initial spike in new cases can be brought down soon.

reply_text:
Hello from Florida
What an interesting time we are in as a global economy. In my neck of the woods on the east coast beaches are closed, stores readily running out of supplies, business are shutting down everyday, police are breaking up beach parties, others getting on social media telling their friends to dine out.
Not much of a spread yet but a well know aerospace facility in my town just got a case of covid-19 and havent shut down. That facility employees hundreds of engineers. I live next door to an Airbnb for outatowners only. I don‚Äôt understand why people are traveling out of state/country right now. I‚Äôm afraid many are not taking this virus seriously.
In terms of Fiverr, it‚Äôs slowed down a bit but steady. I‚Äôm thankful we have the opportunity to work safely from home. THANK YOU Micha and the Fiverr team for building this place for us!! I ended up here during the last recession so I know we are likely in for some hard times ahead but together we can overcome this!

reply_text:
I am in Maryland. East coast of the US. We have one death in the county I live in and over 100 cases state wide. Everything is shut down! Grocery stores are having a hard time keeping stock of disinfecting wipes and general cleaning supplies. They have Senior hours for people over 60 from 7-8am at the stores.
I am a Teacher by day, so off and trying to enjoy the time. No clue when and if we go back to work. Right now it is set for the end of the month to go back, but hard to see how with cases growing.
The biggest issue as I am sure the news has said is testing. It is so limited right now. To get tested requires so much effort, and as it becomes more available, I am sure the numbers will spike significantly.
Watching how different states handle this vs how the Govt is responding is interesting.
I do not want to go into that. I feel horrible for anyone affected by this. Seeing images. from Italy is scary, and I sure hope the US learns from China and Europes lessons and listens.
Only time will tell, and not having a known outcome for this is anxiety producing.

mjensen415:
I want to ask how YOU are doing and if there‚Äôs anything we as a community can do to help support you during this strange time around the world.
I would like the community to come together and arrange for me and my dog and possibly my girlfriend to be airlifted immediately to Pitcairn Island.
Thank you for the kind offer.
More seriously, I‚Äôd really like Fiverr to maybe go with @eoinfinnegan‚Äôs earlier suggestion of Fiverr relaxing St. Levels and maybe putting some UI tweaks in place to make sellers‚Äô lives easier.
I‚Äôve been bombed bya client repeatedly ordering in bulk from my single article gig with 1-day delivery, despite me asking him numerous times to message me before placing bulk orders. I‚Äôve finally lost it and just canceled his last order. However, my stats will likely be ruined soon anyway.
The thing is, this wouldn‚Äôt happen if we had a feature to limit how many of a certain gig package a single buyer can buy at a time.
Another thing that would make life easier is a 24-hour or 48-hour auto-accept feature for disputes. I got bombed yesterday with lots of people who aren‚Äôt replying to extension requests, likely because it is the weekend and they are doing what normies do and are taking time out until Monday.
And would it really be so hard to darken and increase the font size of the fonts in messages, order requirements, and custom offers? - Or let sellers customize this?

Another thing that would make life easier is a 24-hour or 48-hour auto-accept feature for disputes. I got bombed yesterday with lots of people who aren‚Äôt replying to extension requests, likely because it is the weekend and they are doing what normies do and are taking time out until Monday.

reply_text:
Hi everyone! I come from Italy. As you may have already heard, here the situation is truly tragic, especially in Northern Italy. We‚Äôve been in quarantine for 13 days, all non-essential services are closed, and the military and police officers monitor the cities. Many have lost their jobs and self-employed workers are the ones who are suffering a severe blow, economically speaking. Fortunately, I am doing fine. The company I work for allows smart-working and when I don‚Äôt work, I have online lessons and dedicate myself to freelancing ( well, and Netflix too). I‚Äôve noticed that several other companies are demanding for people to work remotely. I imagine that in this tragic scenario the world of work gets adapted to the circumstances and I think this is positive for those who now find it difficult to raise some money.
Either way, I hope you are all fine. Wherever you come from, try to stay safe!

one of daughters friends has it. To say its bad is an understatement and this is (a formerly) healthy 20 something. Now its a waiting game to see if anyone here has it. reply_text:
lenasemenkova:
This is getting ridiculous if I‚Äôm honest.
On my island, we have had no cases but 1 that was sent to the mainland. The only way to get here is by ferry. All businesses are closed and already people are losing their jobs and can‚Äôt pay their bills. It would be easy to prohibit passengers on the ferry and just use the service for goods. This way, life here could continue as something like normal and small businesses would at least stand a chance.
Instead, tourists can get a 10,000 euro fine for not answering the door when a policeman calls to see if they are obeying by quarantine rules. (This means they press buzzers on apartment main entrances that usually don‚Äôt work, and guess what time they call?) Businesses can also get a 3,000 fine for opening and at least one has already been fined for trying to do something productive and having staff on-site doing paintwork and maintenance.
It is all madness.
And if you thought Coronavirus was bad, wait for rat flu!
Mail Online ‚Äì 24 Mar 20
Man who died on bus in China tests positive for virus RATS spread
The victim died on a vehicle in Shandong as he made his way to work and was found to be suffering from hantavirus, which infected rats spread through bites, droppings, urine and saliva.
Then you have that minor problem that is when economies nosedive, public health goes through the floor. Infant mortality rates go up, life expectancy shortens, violent crime goes up, the rate of people choosing to end it all skyrockets, rates of malnutrition go up, disease spreads more easily as a result, homelessness rates skyrocket‚Ä¶
This isn‚Äôt just getting ridiculous, it‚Äôs dangerous, and the aftermath of this is going to be catastrophic. .

reply_text:
I wonder what life will be like a year from now, or two years from now. We have no real leadership here. (edit: I‚Äôm referring to our country, not fiverr.) Nothing is being done at all aside from a handful of scientists in various places studying this. It‚Äôs crazy people can‚Äôt get tested. We can‚Äôt do tele-doctor visits. Not enough masks available for healthcare workers who have to wear two masks, two sets of gloves which they remove the top layer for each patient, etc.
I can‚Äôt imagine what our pitiful little local emergency waiting room must be like, parents with screaming babies waiting for hours, homeless people, all sick and coughing, overworked understaffed nurses. Hope I don‚Äôt have to find out, in person.
A small ray of hope:
They found the virus doesn‚Äôt like hot humid weather, over 63 degrees f. It slows it down.
They also found it does not mutate due to the way it‚Äôs put together, unlike the flu, so any vaccine will likely be permanent.
Best hope: a year from now a good vaccine will be available to anyone. And the drug that shows so much promise is widely available to anyone who needs it.
Try your hardest to keep from getting it in the meantime. Do whatever it takes.

I think almost every person thinks of scenarios that are not likely to happen. Me too‚Ä¶
But as a human, I know my genes will do whatever it takes to survive.
That‚Äôs why I wear mask, wash hands end spend as much as possible time at home, where I feel safe at the moment.
I try to think of positives that could happen in future, like people‚Äôs changed mindset, cleaner water, cleaner air, singing birds, animals re-born, and so on. It makes me feel better than catastrophic future.
We will see later. Stay safe!

reply_text: Our Ministry of Health commissioned a bunch of ads and infographics explaining to people how not to get the virus in a fun visual way. One of the tips was to avoid wild animals at all costs. But ‚Äúwild‚Äù got lost in translation because the translator was bad at their job. The designer was even more of a genius because they illustrated this tip with a golden retriever instead of a boar or a bat. That triggered a wave of panicked citizens bringing their dogs to the shelters, throwing them out to the streets and occasionally putting them down. Be good at your job, people. Wash your hands and think of the puppies.

reply_text:
In a week‚Äôs time, there has been more than 330 people diagnosed with COVID-19 and 3 Arkansas residents have died from the disease. We have yet to see a huge number of cases here but, according to our mayor, he doesn‚Äôt trust the numbers. He feels the number is much more than four in our county. We‚Äôve been told that the hospitals have the test but don‚Äôt want to use them unless they absolutely have no choice.
In fact, from what I‚Äôm hearing, the hospitals are turning people away and not testing those even with outward symptoms of this disease. They just tell them to quarantine themselves and wait for 14 days unless they get worse.
I‚Äôm trying to avoid the crowds as much as possible. It was 80+ degrees here today, and I would have walked our local park, but got the word that large groups of people were in the park with their kids. No thank you!
Stay well everyone!

Everybody has stocked up on food so the supermarkets have been under pressure.

Stay home, Stay safe.

So I work with theaters a lot (now it‚Äôs obviously slowing down due to the virus because no one can have shows). But I got an order from one of them today. I asked if they were sure they wanted to proceed given the situation because wouldn‚Äôt want to charge people for something that will get cancelled 100%.
They said: ‚ÄúAll the shows are being hosted online-everyone does their part via webcam from their homes, everything has changed and we are making it work!‚Äù
And it just made me happy to see how people change their process and adapt to the hardships. If there is a silver lining in all of this, it‚Äôs how creative and inspiring the human spirit really is.

reply_text:
We all need to adapt to not leaving our homes, probably for a very long time. I can‚Äôt see this getting better until a vaccine is developed and widely distributed to everyone, which will be at least a year from now.
I hope everyone here is prepared to stay inside that long. Going any place where there are people puts us at risk. The more people now who are not going out, the sooner our health care systems can find ways to deal with all the patients they have, and the fewer of us will get the virus.
I have food delivered to my home. I only touch the bags with rubber gloves on and I wash all of it. I leave the bags of canned foods without touching them for three days. It can take that long for the virus to die when it‚Äôs on bags or other surfaces.
There may come a time when I can no longer get food delivered and I‚Äôm sure most people here still need to go out to get food. Please wear a mask or cloth over your nose and mouth when you go out.
We are actually experiencing nature adjusting and balancing out our population to protect the earth, the air and lower pollution.

reply_text:
I‚Äôm in one of the most affected states in the USA (NJ) where we have nearly 50,000 cases already. We‚Äôre simply not leaving the house at all. Grocery delivery has shut down everywhere around here, and stores aren‚Äôt offering pickup services either. We have people in delicate health in the household. So, we‚Äôre living on canned and boxed foods that go through a rigorous self-quarantine and decontamination of their own once they hit our porch. It‚Äôs crazy, and maybe excessive, but taking no chances.
Hope everyone‚Äôs being safe and staying sane out there. A good time to take up some stress relief habits and watch comedies or read light-hearted books.

Hi everyone. If you‚Äôre like me, you‚Äôve been getting these ‚ÄúWhat are we doing‚Äù emails from companies about COVID-19. And‚Ä¶ that‚Äôs great. Thanks for letting me know random company I bought that one thing from 5 years ago.
I want to ask how YOU are doing and if there‚Äôs anything we as a community can do to help support you during this strange time around the world.
Personally, I‚Äôm in the SF Bay Area and we‚Äôre on FULL ‚Äúshelter in place 45‚Äù orders. I‚Äôm working from home now with three kids (all under 6) so ‚Äúwork time‚Äù has gotten a lot crazier (only so many times I can hear my daughter sing ‚ÄúLET IT GOOOOO 37‚Äù).

reply_text:
Hiii,
Never did I expect COVID to change life as we know it this drastically. Nearly everyone I know has been let go from their jobs. I was promptly sent to work from home then blindingly let go a week later.
Hawaii is on a lockdown for the next month and staying home is mind numbingly boring. I‚Äôm hoping Fiverr can help out in keeping me occupied.
Stay safe and indoors everyone!

Sorry to hear of all that! What a nightmare.
We have no working plumbing currently in our ancient house and I‚Äôm afraid to let in anyone to fix it since our area is a very high covid area and I don‚Äôt want to be around any strangers.
Yesterday we had a complete blackout for a while. Between no plumbing and no lights or electricity it was surreal. At least in a cave we could build a fire and use the outside ‚Äúrestroom‚Äù.
I found myself yelling out the front door to the neighbors to find out what was happening with the electricity. We aren‚Äôt supposed to go outside at all here. I felt like a trapped animal.

reply_text:
Many states here in the U.S. are slowly opening their economies - my state included. To say I‚Äôm nervous about how this will all play out is an understatement. As much as I want to get back into the gym or lift weights in the local park, another part of me is saying, this is going to get worse before it gets better.
Last night, instead of attending a concert in Memphis to see Motionless in White, I was at home. The concert was postponed (understandable) and who knows if the concert will even happen. The bright spot of the whole thing is that my school will remain shut down for the rest of the academic year. Now, I do need to go in once a week to get things done such as auditing for next year and payments.
As it stands now, my job is being terminated due to restructuring. I was actually called to ask if I wanted another position in the school as a parapro. While it‚Äôs not what I want all the way around, I know I can do the job and will do it as I do anything else in my life. I await the final decision from the board to see if they will make the approval. So, we‚Äôll see!
Thankfully, the Fiverr work has increased, which may be due in part to finding my best gig on page one again with the culmination of an ad I ran.
In the grand scheme of things, I‚Äôm just playing the wait and see game and doing work when it comes in.
Stay safe and healthy Fiverr friends!

reply_text:
QUARANTINE RESULTS REPORT
Since I do reports all the time at work I find it natural to make a report on what I did during quarantine since this is the last Q-day in my country (Croatia). Starting tomorrow business should be slowly returning to normal.
So:
I published 2 new books
I wrote 3 new books and prepared drafts for 12 more
I wrote 5 e-books for students struggling to learn online since schools are closed
I started Fiverr seller account and earned 92 USD
I designed furniture for my backyard and build it together with my crafty neighbor
I repurposed frame of the old trampoline into the gym area
I planted some flowers for the first time in my life
I draw a big ‚ÄúNO SMOKING‚Äù sign in my backyard
I started a YouTube channel and helped a kid who was being harassed by others on the live stream
And
I cleaned and organized my office (this lasted for one day and now it is back to random mess)
I discovered there is nothing wrong with my car battery, for some reason car wants to start only if the shift gear is in a certain position
I gain 10 pounds (and then I decided to make gym outside :D)
I actually planted seeds of watermelon next to flowers.
END OF REPORT
Marina no smoking

Thank you for the Mexico part. I wish. Then I would know Spanish, my dream language.
I feel sorry for my old self. I had this backyard for 39 years and my day was wake up, go to university, do lectures for 8 hours, then do e-learning for 6 hours, and go to sleep, tomorrow, repeat. All the years of life wasted. I never wanted to invest in the apartment and backyard since it is rented, not mine. I finally got to my senses I need to enjoy in today.

I‚Äôm sorry for your sisters situation. However, she might be lucky if France is still treating oncology patients. In Malta and lots of other countries, most cancer screening and treatment is pretty much on hold at the moment. I have a friend with lung cancer who hasn‚Äôt been to the hospital in weeks.
ldnarquitectura:
COVID19 is not so dangerous as cancer.
More people have died in building accidents on Malta this year than they have of COVID. However, the constriction industry is the only industry that has been allowed to continue operating as normal throughout the pandemic. Apparently, the cost to the economy would be to great if they ceased operations.
Then you have the suicide rate in the U.S. In some states, they have already recorded more suicides this year than during the entirety on 2019. Sadly, most people aren‚Äôt interested in looking at the bigger picture.
I hope your sister recovers and that you can get to see her soon.

thread_name: Support for SMBs and Freelancers during the spread of COVID-19
thread_text:
A letter to the Fiverr community & beyond.
The worst thing about the COVID-19 (aka Coronavirus) is the uncertainty that surrounds it. How dangerous is it really? Will it last through the summer? Will there be a vaccine soon?
As the Coronavirus continues to spread across the globe, governments, businesses, and individuals are trying to work out what it means for them, how to protect themselves and how they can help.
In many ways, Fiverr is an embodiment of remote work already. In ordinary times, our community enjoys an engagement that allows them to have freedom over their time and location, but in these uncertain times, it also provides a safer environment to work in.
It is becoming increasingly clear that businesses around the world are likely to be impacted by the changes imposed because of the virus. More people are being instructed to spend less time in public places and more time at home. Despite the uncertainty and restrictions on movement, life and work will and must continue and the Fiverr Community, in particular, are highly accustomed to rapid change with the ability to adjust. And while the long term impact of the virus is hard to predict, in the short term, businesses will have to think about moving the majority of their activity online.
We‚Äôve been thinking about ways in which we can help our community of small and medium-sized businesses (SMBs) manage in this new environment and decided to put together a new website dedicated to helping SMBs in these uncertain times. You can find the new website at www.SMBhelp.com 379. It will provide guidance, tips, and tools for those who have questions about how to put more of their business online. Here is what you will be able to find on the new website right now: General information regarding the impact of the virus on businesses; General tips on how to take your business online, and if you are already online ‚Äì how to promote it; Links to products and tools being offered as special deals to SMBs right now by companies around the world; Free courses that Fiverr is donating, and, in addition, we are going to offer 24/7 customer service support team to answer your questions and concerns about your business. We will do our best to help in any way we can. We are in this together and working together makes all of us stronger.
Millions of people around the world are finding themselves in a new business reality, quarantined in their homes or with major travel restrictions, we hope that by offering these resources for free it will create more opportunities for more people, to take their business online, to learn new skills, or to start the business they have been dreaming of.
Lastly, if there are resources you think we should include in the new site, please send them to us or post them on social media using the #SMBhelp hashtag.
Make sure that you continue to follow your local government‚Äôs guidance and please stay safe.
Yours,
Micha Kaufman
Founder & CEO, Fiverr
reply_text: N/A

The worst thing about the COVID-19 (aka Coronavirus) is the uncertainty that surrounds it. How dangerous is it really? Will it last through the summer? Will there be a vaccine soon?
As the Coronavirus continues to spread across the globe, governments, businesses, and individuals are trying to work out what it means for them, how to protect themselves and how they can help.
In many ways, Fiverr is an embodiment of remote work already. In ordinary times, our community enjoys an engagement that allows them to have freedom over their time and location, but in these uncertain times, it also provides a safer environment to work in.
It is becoming increasingly clear that businesses around the world are likely to be impacted by the changes imposed because of the virus. More people are being instructed to spend less time in public places and more time at home. Despite the uncertainty and restrictions on movement, life and work will and must continue and the Fiverr Community, in particular, are highly accustomed to rapid change with the ability to adjust. And while the long term impact of the virus is hard to predict, in the short term, businesses will have to think about moving the majority of their activity online.
We‚Äôve been thinking about ways in which we can help our community of small and medium-sized businesses (SMBs) manage in this new environment and decided to put together a new website dedicated to helping SMBs in these uncertain times. You can find the new website at www.SMBhelp.com 379. It will provide guidance, tips, and tools for those who have questions about how to put more of their business online. Here is what you will be able to find on the new website right now: General information regarding the impact of the virus on businesses; General tips on how to take your business online, and if you are already online ‚Äì how to promote it; Links to products and tools being offered as special deals to SMBs right now by companies around the world; Free courses that Fiverr is donating, and, in addition, we are going to offer 24/7 customer service support team to answer your questions and concerns about your business. We will do our best to help in any way we can. We are in this together and working together makes all of us stronger.
Millions of people around the world are finding themselves in a new business reality, quarantined in their homes or with major travel restrictions, we hope that by offering these resources for free it will create more opportunities for more people, to take their business online, to learn new skills, or to start the business they have been dreaming of.
Lastly, if there are resources you think we should include in the new site, please send them to us or post them on social media using the #SMBhelp hashtag.
Make sure that you continue to follow your local government‚Äôs guidance and please stay safe.
Yours,
Micha Kaufman
Founder & CEO, Fiverr
reply_text: Thank you so much for your information and I should take care of our health and pray for COVID-19 of our creators.

thread_name: Support for SMBs and Freelancers during the spread of COVID-19
thread_text:
A letter to the Fiverr community & beyond.
The worst thing about the COVID-19 (aka Coronavirus) is the uncertainty that surrounds it. How dangerous is it really? Will it last through the summer? Will there be a vaccine soon?
As the Coronavirus continues to spread across the globe, governments, businesses, and individuals are trying to work out what it means for them, how to protect themselves and how they can help.
In many ways, Fiverr is an embodiment of remote work already. In ordinary times, our community enjoys an engagement that allows them to have freedom over their time and location, but in these uncertain times, it also provides a safer environment to work in.
It is becoming increasingly clear that businesses around the world are likely to be impacted by the changes imposed because of the virus. More people are being instructed to spend less time in public places and more time at home. Despite the uncertainty and restrictions on movement, life and work will and must continue and the Fiverr Community, in particular, are highly accustomed to rapid change with the ability to adjust. And while the long term impact of the virus is hard to predict, in the short term, businesses will have to think about moving the majority of their activity online.
We‚Äôve been thinking about ways in which we can help our community of small and medium-sized businesses (SMBs) manage in this new environment and decided to put together a new website dedicated to helping SMBs in these uncertain times. You can find the new website at www.SMBhelp.com 379. It will provide guidance, tips, and tools for those who have questions about how to put more of their business online. Here is what you will be able to find on the new website right now: General information regarding the impact of the virus on businesses; General tips on how to take your business online, and if you are already online ‚Äì how to promote it; Links to products and tools being offered as special deals to SMBs right now by companies around the world; Free courses that Fiverr is donating, and, in addition, we are going to offer 24/7 customer service support team to answer your questions and concerns about your business. We will do our best to help in any way we can. We are in this together and working together makes all of us stronger.
Millions of people around the world are finding themselves in a new business reality, quarantined in their homes or with major travel restrictions, we hope that by offering these resources for free it will create more opportunities for more people, to take their business online, to learn new skills, or to start the business they have been dreaming of.
Lastly, if there are resources you think we should include in the new site, please send them to us or post them on social media using the #SMBhelp hashtag.
Make sure that you continue to follow your local government‚Äôs guidance and please stay safe.
Yours,
Micha Kaufman
Founder & CEO, Fiverr
reply_text:
This information is the best information. I really thankful to fiverr having such a nice and knowledgeable person.
Thank you

reply_text:
Now if only Fiverr could devote that much energy into removing the problems that penalize sellers for what buyers do wrong! Perhaps not as strong a public relations opportunity.
Sorry, but these things frustrate me. We‚Äôre supposed to oooh and aahhh about this gesture, but it‚Äôs a deflection of the systemic issues within the platform.
I‚Äôm not saying Fiverr owes us anything because of Corona ‚Äì not at all. I‚Äôm just saying that if they‚Äôre going to essentially brag about the good they‚Äôre doing for sellers, they should also address the unfairness that they‚Äôve attached to the selling experience here ‚Äì stuff we‚Äôve been venting about here and elsewhere for literally years but nothing changes.
After all, the unjust elements of Fiverr affect sellers‚Äô income from the platform the most and no amount of free resources is going to change that.

In many ways, Fiverr is an embodiment of remote work already. In ordinary times, our community enjoys an engagement that allows them to have freedom over their time and location, but in these uncertain times, it also provides a safer environment to work in.
It is becoming increasingly clear that businesses around the world are likely to be impacted by the changes imposed because of the virus. More people are being instructed to spend less time in public places and more time at home. Despite the uncertainty and restrictions on movement, life and work will and must continue and the Fiverr Community, in particular, are highly accustomed to rapid change with the ability to adjust. And while the long term impact of the virus is hard to predict, in the short term, businesses will have to think about moving the majority of their activity online.
We‚Äôve been thinking about ways in which we can help our community of small and medium-sized businesses (SMBs) manage in this new environment and decided to put together a new website dedicated to helping SMBs in these uncertain times. You can find the new website at www.SMBhelp.com 379. It will provide guidance, tips, and tools for those who have questions about how to put more of their business online. Here is what you will be able to find on the new website right now: General information regarding the impact of the virus on businesses; General tips on how to take your business online, and if you are already online ‚Äì how to promote it; Links to products and tools being offered as special deals to SMBs right now by companies around the world; Free courses that Fiverr is donating, and, in addition, we are going to offer 24/7 customer service support team to answer your questions and concerns about your business. We will do our best to help in any way we can. We are in this together and working together makes all of us stronger.
Millions of people around the world are finding themselves in a new business reality, quarantined in their homes or with major travel restrictions, we hope that by offering these resources for free it will create more opportunities for more people, to take their business online, to learn new skills, or to start the business they have been dreaming of.
Lastly, if there are resources you think we should include in the new site, please send them to us or post them on social media using the #SMBhelp hashtag.
Make sure that you continue to follow your local government‚Äôs guidance and please stay safe.
Yours,
Micha Kaufman
Founder & CEO, Fiverr

reply_text:
Hi Matt @mjensen415,
Actually, there is something Fiverr could do to help its seller freelancer community in a direct and probably not too complicated way (a bit of coding and sending out automated emails, I think).
As it‚Äôs possible that some of us may have to apply for government funds or a mortgage respite, prove to their health insurance that they don‚Äôt earn much or at all due to this pandemic to not have to keep paying their monthly dues based on last year‚Äôs earnings/tax declaration, etc.,
a ‚Äúpaper‚Äù (email) from Fiverr stating the seller‚Äôs revenue for any given month could be more helpful and get less suspicious looks than that csv file one can download. Staff in such organisations often don‚Äôt know much if anything about freelancing or at least platforms like Fiverr/the gig economy, too, and often ask for ‚Äúsomething official‚Äù.
Something that looks credible and official, with Fiverr‚Äôs address and such, that states something like:
XY is registered on our platform as a freelancer and earned $$$ revenue in (February 2020).
I‚Äôm sure Fiverr has people who can make sure that that ‚Äúrevenue statement‚Äù will be fine from a legal standpoint for Fiverr.
This has been already suggested before COVID-19, as something like that, especially as a yearly statement, would be really useful for tax and other purposes, but I think in the face of the current situation, it might just have become even more relevant.
I hope this can be considered/passed on to the relevant people. Thanks!

As the Coronavirus continues to spread across the globe, governments, businesses, and individuals are trying to work out what it means for them, how to protect themselves and how they can help.
In many ways, Fiverr is an embodiment of remote work already. In ordinary times, our community enjoys an engagement that allows them to have freedom over their time and location, but in these uncertain times, it also provides a safer environment to work in.
It is becoming increasingly clear that businesses around the world are likely to be impacted by the changes imposed because of the virus. More people are being instructed to spend less time in public places and more time at home. Despite the uncertainty and restrictions on movement, life and work will and must continue and the Fiverr Community, in particular, are highly accustomed to rapid change with the ability to adjust. And while the long term impact of the virus is hard to predict, in the short term, businesses will have to think about moving the majority of their activity online.
We‚Äôve been thinking about ways in which we can help our community of small and medium-sized businesses (SMBs) manage in this new environment and decided to put together a new website dedicated to helping SMBs in these uncertain times. You can find the new website at www.SMBhelp.com 379. It will provide guidance, tips, and tools for those who have questions about how to put more of their business online. Here is what you will be able to find on the new website right now: General information regarding the impact of the virus on businesses; General tips on how to take your business online, and if you are already online ‚Äì how to promote it; Links to products and tools being offered as special deals to SMBs right now by companies around the world; Free courses that Fiverr is donating, and, in addition, we are going to offer 24/7 customer service support team to answer your questions and concerns about your business. We will do our best to help in any way we can. We are in this together and working together makes all of us stronger.
Millions of people around the world are finding themselves in a new business reality, quarantined in their homes or with major travel restrictions, we hope that by offering these resources for free it will create more opportunities for more people, to take their business online, to learn new skills, or to start the business they have been dreaming of.
Lastly, if there are resources you think we should include in the new site, please send them to us or post them on social media using the #SMBhelp hashtag.
Make sure that you continue to follow your local government‚Äôs guidance and please stay safe.
Yours,
Micha Kaufman
Founder & CEO, Fiverr

thread_name: Support for SMBs and Freelancers during the spread of COVID-19
thread_text:
A letter to the Fiverr community & beyond.
The worst thing about the COVID-19 (aka Coronavirus) is the uncertainty that surrounds it. How dangerous is it really? Will it last through the summer? Will there be a vaccine soon?
As the Coronavirus continues to spread across the globe, governments, businesses, and individuals are trying to work out what it means for them, how to protect themselves and how they can help.
In many ways, Fiverr is an embodiment of remote work already. In ordinary times, our community enjoys an engagement that allows them to have freedom over their time and location, but in these uncertain times, it also provides a safer environment to work in.
It is becoming increasingly clear that businesses around the world are likely to be impacted by the changes imposed because of the virus. More people are being instructed to spend less time in public places and more time at home. Despite the uncertainty and restrictions on movement, life and work will and must continue and the Fiverr Community, in particular, are highly accustomed to rapid change with the ability to adjust. And while the long term impact of the virus is hard to predict, in the short term, businesses will have to think about moving the majority of their activity online.
We‚Äôve been thinking about ways in which we can help our community of small and medium-sized businesses (SMBs) manage in this new environment and decided to put together a new website dedicated to helping SMBs in these uncertain times. You can find the new website at www.SMBhelp.com 379. It will provide guidance, tips, and tools for those who have questions about how to put more of their business online. Here is what you will be able to find on the new website right now: General information regarding the impact of the virus on businesses; General tips on how to take your business online, and if you are already online ‚Äì how to promote it; Links to products and tools being offered as special deals to SMBs right now by companies around the world; Free courses that Fiverr is donating, and, in addition, we are going to offer 24/7 customer service support team to answer your questions and concerns about your business. We will do our best to help in any way we can. We are in this together and working together makes all of us stronger.
Millions of people around the world are finding themselves in a new business reality, quarantined in their homes or with major travel restrictions, we hope that by offering these resources for free it will create more opportunities for more people, to take their business online, to learn new skills, or to start the business they have been dreaming of.
Lastly, if there are resources you think we should include in the new site, please send them to us or post them on social media using the #SMBhelp hashtag.
Make sure that you continue to follow your local government‚Äôs guidance and please stay safe.
Yours,
Micha Kaufman
Founder & CEO, Fiverr

thread_name: Support for SMBs and Freelancers during the spread of COVID-19
thread_text:
A letter to the Fiverr community & beyond.
The worst thing about the COVID-19 (aka Coronavirus) is the uncertainty that surrounds it. How dangerous is it really? Will it last through the summer? Will there be a vaccine soon?
As the Coronavirus continues to spread across the globe, governments, businesses, and individuals are trying to work out what it means for them, how to protect themselves and how they can help.
In many ways, Fiverr is an embodiment of remote work already. In ordinary times, our community enjoys an engagement that allows them to have freedom over their time and location, but in these uncertain times, it also provides a safer environment to work in.
It is becoming increasingly clear that businesses around the world are likely to be impacted by the changes imposed because of the virus. More people are being instructed to spend less time in public places and more time at home. Despite the uncertainty and restrictions on movement, life and work will and must continue and the Fiverr Community, in particular, are highly accustomed to rapid change with the ability to adjust. And while the long term impact of the virus is hard to predict, in the short term, businesses will have to think about moving the majority of their activity online.
We‚Äôve been thinking about ways in which we can help our community of small and medium-sized businesses (SMBs) manage in this new environment and decided to put together a new website dedicated to helping SMBs in these uncertain times. You can find the new website at www.SMBhelp.com 379. It will provide guidance, tips, and tools for those who have questions about how to put more of their business online. Here is what you will be able to find on the new website right now: General information regarding the impact of the virus on businesses; General tips on how to take your business online, and if you are already online ‚Äì how to promote it; Links to products and tools being offered as special deals to SMBs right now by companies around the world; Free courses that Fiverr is donating, and, in addition, we are going to offer 24/7 customer service support team to answer your questions and concerns about your business. We will do our best to help in any way we can. We are in this together and working together makes all of us stronger.
Millions of people around the world are finding themselves in a new business reality, quarantined in their homes or with major travel restrictions, we hope that by offering these resources for free it will create more opportunities for more people, to take their business online, to learn new skills, or to start the business they have been dreaming of.
Lastly, if there are resources you think we should include in the new site, please send them to us or post them on social media using the #SMBhelp hashtag.
Make sure that you continue to follow your local government‚Äôs guidance and please stay safe.
Yours,
Micha Kaufman
Founder & CEO, Fiverr
reply_text: Thanks for creating the post. Stay home stay safe.

thread_name: Would Fiverr be a good plan B?
frequent_posters: atefattef, lokman_akoon, tamoo12, jansonjustin, landongrace, yarasin, samyaknetwork, master_piece96, jake_hopkins, psychicbunny, fibocci, hrizvi2000, lilychinadancer, imagination7413
thread_text:
Hey guys,
My name is Atef, I own a digital agency in Canada.
With the recent COVID-19 outbreak, the business went south. It‚Äôs so hard to find new (local) clients since everyone is afraid to pay. Even our current customers are delaying payments.
I‚Äôm new to Fiverr. i wonder how has it been for freelancers that have been working in Fiverr for a while? Did it slow down?
Would this be a good plan b for myself? Or is it too late to join?
Thanks!
reply_text:
Welcome to the Fiverr forums.
You‚Äôre in the right category to find the answers, and this is probably the most active thread on the topic, so feel free to join in the discussion: Coronavirus (COVID-19) Impacts On Freelancing! 8
As for the specific question of ‚Äògood plan B‚Äô, I can say that there has been a huge influx of people thinking the exact same thing. It all depends on if the plan was/is actually a plan and not a whim.
You‚Äôve been here since December, according to your account, so you already know that it‚Äôs not as simple as making a gig to make sales. The ‚Äòconditions‚Äô are even more saturated now. Plan B might still work, but it‚Äôll take work, a lot of work, to make it as a freelancer, so be sure to research and plan accordingly.
‚ÄúIf you fail to plan, you are planning to fail.‚Äù (Attributed to Benjamin Franklin)

thread_name: Would Fiverr be a good plan B?
frequent_posters: atefattef, lokman_akoon, tamoo12, jansonjustin, landongrace, yarasin, samyaknetwork, master_piece96, jake_hopkins, psychicbunny, fibocci, hrizvi2000, lilychinadancer, imagination7413
thread_text:
Hey guys,
My name is Atef, I own a digital agency in Canada.
With the recent COVID-19 outbreak, the business went south. It‚Äôs so hard to find new (local) clients since everyone is afraid to pay. Even our current customers are delaying payments.
I‚Äôm new to Fiverr. i wonder how has it been for freelancers that have been working in Fiverr for a while? Did it slow down?
Would this be a good plan b for myself? Or is it too late to join?
Thanks!
reply_text:
I would consider focusing on clients that are moving in this economic environment. That has been a bigger issue for me than which sales platform. Do you have current customers that are working more in this season? I see tons of new video commercials and ads from companies that are distributing media right now. Much of the work can be completed online and not in person.
I have an active account on Fiverr. I have seen a 30% increase in my business during the crisis. People have gone home and now they have time to complete the things they have been too busy to finish. They are less distracted now.
There is economic unrest which will keep some people from paying their bills. You and I just need a small percentage of work from the people who can spend.
The pest control business also suffers during times like this. It‚Äôs easy to hold on to cash and be 30 or 60 days behind on paying the pest control bill. I have friends in the business who almost go bankrupt every time it happens. It really causes a cashflow problem for them when 80% of their customer don‚Äôt paiy this month‚Äôs bill.

thread_name: Would Fiverr be a good plan B?
frequent_posters: atefattef, lokman_akoon, tamoo12, jansonjustin, landongrace, yarasin, samyaknetwork, master_piece96, jake_hopkins, psychicbunny, fibocci, hrizvi2000, lilychinadancer, imagination7413

Yeah thats the direction I‚Äôm shifting towards. Many of my clients are local business owners that had to shut down, and some had to let go of a few of their employees.
The thing is all of this is pretty recent, and noone really knows how long it will be before it all goes back to normal.
But what we know for sure for every additional day it persists another business owner will have to close up shop. Making the market for us smaller and smaller by the day.

reply_text:
I honestly just wear a mask everywhere just because I‚Äôm sick and tired of taking it on and off. I‚Äôll just put it on for everyone to leave me alone. And to stop being tempted to touch my face.
Two former co-workers of mine have died from COVID. One was 33 and died in a week after starting to exhibit symptoms. Another one was 41 and died in around a month. We weren‚Äôt close and haven‚Äôt talked in years.
I believe there is a penalty of roughly $1500 for not wearing a mask in a ‚Äúpublic place‚Äù where I live. People don‚Äôt seem to care, everyone just carries a mask in their pocket or under their jaw to quickly put it on if the police come.
My inner circle is pretty small and I don‚Äôt leave the house much.
Haven‚Äôt been tested for COVID and I‚Äôm not going to until there is a reason (me having symptoms or me having to travel somewhere).

reply_text:
I live in Italy. Here we must wear masks in indoor public areas - such as shops, supermarkets or when travelling by public transport. But in outdoor public places wearing masks is not compulsory anymore at the moment (it used to be obligatory during lockdown, but right now we are only advised to do so).
Personally I think it‚Äôs always a good idea to wear a mask whenever a 2-metre social distance can‚Äôt be maintained. Equally important is hand hygiene. I carry my hand sanitiser whenever I am out in public, and as soon as I‚Äôm back home I wash my hands with soap.
Unfortunately where I live there are lots of people who are gathering in large groups as if nothing had happened.

reply_text:
Greetings from Tokyo.
Fortunately nobody I know in person has been infected.
I wear masks pretty much at all times, but due to the recent heat, when I walk to the station I use a quiet route with less people and I hold the mask in my hand. As I get closer to the station I will put it back on.
I see people walking on quiet/empty streets without masks, but in most cases I can
see them wearing it around their chin, hold it in their pockets, or in their hands.
I‚Äôm assuming they will put it back on once they reach a more crowded area.
I‚Äôd say 99.8% of everyone I see on the train are wearing masks.
We‚Äôre not forced, but since wearing masks in public was a very normal thing for us way before the covid, I guess we don‚Äôt have that much problems.
Having that said, the number of people getting infected is still increasing.
A lot of people are letting their guard down I suppose.

reply_text:
Once we‚Äôre on the subject, does anyone have mandatory temperature checks before entering public places and how accurate are those?
My temperature is consistently 35.0 - 35.2 Celcius according to those devices (while the ‚Äúnormal‚Äù temperature is 36.5 - 36.8) so it shouldn‚Äôt be humanly possible. I had 36.0 for a week after a blood loss and I had trouble sitting up. Definitely not in the mood for shopping, or movies, or bar-hopping.
It‚Äôs a new technology and it shows results in a matter of seconds so I‚Äôm not sure how accurate it is or if there is a certain process to it (add 1 degree to the result you get or something) but it‚Äôs always such a joke when they proudly announce that you‚Äôre basically a frost giant at this point so you can pass.

thread_name: Rapid growth in freelance jobs due to COVID-19
thread_text:
In the second quarter of this year, the time between the period of April to June , job openings in the freelance sector increased by up to 25% when compared to the first quarter of the year.
When last year‚Äôs second quarter is being compared to this second quarter, the posting of freelance jobs has increased to 41% i.e. six hundred and five thousand according to the some reports.
Covid-19 is expected to strengthen the gig economy and rise in freelance projects. Demand for freelance jobs is on the rise as organizations get increasingly used to the virtual workplace and remote working, and in some cases, cutting fixed employee costs post the Coronavirus outbreak.
What are your views on this? Will this rise keep on increasing until a cure is found or is it just a temporary rise?
reply_text:
For me I think it will be a temporary rise since most people prefer the 9 to 5 job because of some benefits like using the companies car, house allowance and those sort of things.
Plus freelancing can sometimes be monotonous. Yes you will have flexibility, but working alone without any social contacts may lead to anxiety, mental illness and even it may affect your physical health.
I personally prefer freelancing since it gives me the chance to expand my skills by tackling different projects and working with different clients. Who you work for also determines your success.
If you have a good boss, you are most likely to become really good at what you do. Freelancing will give me the opportunity to work for different clients and satisfy different needs.
Best Regards,
josh01omondi

thread_name: 6 Ways COVID-19 is Changing the Tech Industry (& Our Lives)
thread_text:
1. Virtual Tools Are Now the Norm for Everyday Life
Over the past several months, families went from typical public school attenders to home-schooling households. It‚Äôs a major shift, but a necessary one to keep little ones safe. This is all made possible with online schooling using tablets and laptops.
At the same time, consumers are changing how they‚Äôre engaging with businesses. Take, for example, banking ‚Äî apps and AI tools are being promoted heavily by financial institutions to cut down on in-person visits and prevent bottlenecks in their phone lines.
Now, there‚Äôs an adoption of touchless biometric tech for customers to check out with. Soon, eye scanners may begin replacing fingerprint and chip card readers.
But what‚Äôs most notable is how people now work. Roughly 50% of Americans are currently working from home full-time. Anyone who doesn‚Äôt perform manual labor is now operating from their home office, dining room table, or patio. Thanks to tech companies like Zoom, GoToMeeting, and Asana, these companies were able to transition their workforce into a remote staff.
2. Telehealth Platforms Take Over the Health Industry
Patients who don‚Äôt need emergency medical care are finding themselves face-to-face with their physicians via webcam. Telehealth platforms are making it possible for doctors and their patients to continue their visits without exploiting themselves to possible COVID-19 infection.
This includes various medical industries, such as physical therapy, primary care, and psychiatric therapy.
Having sessions from the comfort of your couch could become the preferred method in the future.
3. Tracking Tools Will Diminish Individual Privacy
Contact tracing ‚Äî it‚Äôs the phrase of the new decade, thanks to COVID-19. And because of it, individuals may lose more privacy than they‚Äôre comfortable with.
In case you haven‚Äôt heard ‚Äî contact tracing is the government‚Äôs attempt to put together a task force (and apps) to keep track of who interacts with who. All in the name of hunting down who may have been exposed to those infected by CV-19.
Smartphones will be the main source of this information, and tech companies are jumping on the gravy boat. Companies like Safer and SwipedOn already have smartphone apps ready to go for business use.
4. Virtual Reality Becomes a Necessity (vs. a Luxury)
The emergence of VR technology was long-awaited by older generations who grew up watching sci-fi movies like Total Recall and Demolition Man.
Now that it‚Äôs here, it‚Äôs become a luxury tool to enjoy video games, movies, and social interactions in a whole new way. But now, with a pandemic at everyone‚Äôs doorstep, virtual reality is becoming more of a necessity.
Today, VR headsets and AR (augmented reality) are being used to view virtual tours of homes, shop for home goods, and to travel the world (since many are still stuck at home). It‚Äôs also being used for education, medical care, and employee training.
5. Drone Deliveries Will Become the Norm
It was always inevitable that drones would one day become the delivery drivers of e-commerce purchases. But it was COVID-19 that sped up the process.
Now, there‚Äôs an expectation that federal regulators will streamline the process of delivery drone adoption. Even if it means cutting red tape faster than usual.
These drones will be implemented in lifesaving efforts, which include delivering medicine to the elderly and sick, or even test kits to households.
You can already see drones used for surveillance and monitoring by local police across different counties.
6. Remote Work is Likely to Stay
You have roughly 80% of remote workers saying their happier operating from home. Another 43% are even hoping they can continue working remotely after the pandemic ends.
If businesses pay attention to the needs and demands of their workforce, then you may see remote work here for the long-term.
The paradigm is also shifting for small business owners and entrepreneurs. Those in need of workers who are affordable and flexible are using platforms like Fiverr to find top talent.
Some are looking for web developers to transform their brick-and-mortars into virtual stores. Others are looking to expand their website services to include chatbots to meet the increasing demand for digital sales, customer service, and tech support.

One of my sisters works in customer support and her boss, the giant doofus that he is, kept declining to let people work from home because ‚Äúit‚Äôs not work, it‚Äôs a vacation‚Äù when pandemic first hit. He was eventually forced to let people stay home but only after subway got closed due to quarantine. And it turned out, the overall productivity went up. Turned out, him running into the room screaming at his employees at random intervals through the day wasn‚Äôt that much of a motivator. Funny that.

Not necessarily ‚Äúall the time‚Äù. I used to work for a company who‚Äôd allow you to take 1 day a week to work from home. My friend now works for a company that allows 2 days. Those conditions were in place in pre-covid world and are still there now. Some flexibility introduced into the rigid corporate structures is a positive thing.
The entire construct of office 9-5 (9-6 in my country, btw)) = discipline = productivity has taken a big hit and it‚Äôs a good thing also. People are most productive when they‚Äôre positively motivated, not when they‚Äôre just trapped inside the corporate culture.

thread_name: Will there be more freelancers in a Post-Covid World?
frequent_posters: infywave, lenasemenkova, parvesislam_efn, revaram077, coerdelion, gina_riley2, bumblepixco, kimberlyhn100, lydiayunita, english_voice
thread_text:
According to Deloitte‚Äôs ‚ÄúFuture of Work Accelerated‚Äù report, 3 in 5 organizations increasing their share of gig workers so as to reduce dependency on full time workforce.
This may increase the amount of freelancers post-covid era.
What are your views on it?
reply_text:
This is an interesting thread! I have been freelance for many years, although I have also worked in staff positions (guaranteed work for guaranteed pay).
In my opinion there is a massive difference in the mindsets of people who are genuinely freelance because they choose to be, and those who are freelance because they have to be.
Those who choose to be freelance tend to be good at what they do, dedicated to the task in hand but also quite fun people to be around.
Those who have to be freelance tend to overthink their work (not always a good trait), they tend to be a little nervous and look for any opportunity to secure a permanent job.
I‚Äôm in my late 40s so I‚Äôve seen a lot of people with the above characteristics in my working life! In my opinion everything will settle down after a while and return to normal.
Existing businesses will start to expand agin, new businesses will begin, people will change careers, retire, etc. The world always move on. It might take a few months or even two or three years‚Ä¶ but the temporary increase in freelancers that we will inevitably see will even out over time.

reply_text:
I think freelancing will continue to grow. With this pandemic, many people with talent have found a new sense of freedom. The joy of doing what they want and when they want to do it.
Of course, there is the startup, which will either make or break someone. Those that rise to the top will always find a way. Those that fail were either never meant to freelance or do not have the talent.
I know when I hire people on this platform for certain jobs, it creates multiple orders. For example, whiteboard animators: I hire seller, they hire a voice over and maybe even a script writer. At the end, 3 people got a job.
I haven‚Äôt written a story in a long time, but when I did and will do again, it involves many sellers. I hire beta reader, editor, proofed, cover designers, etc.
I am due to retire in about 2 years. I am really looking forward to that date. I can start doing some real freelancing. I want to write more ebook, stories, blogs, etc.
I think 5r is a great place for professional editors, proofreaders, etc. to make a side income. The only thing is no filter for people with no skills.
I‚Äôve found many talented people here that saved me money and also some pretty bad ones that have wasted my time and money.
Oh well, you win some, you lose some.

reply_text:
Business did fluctuate a bit but not so much more than within a similar time period pre COVID, and I was ‚Äúbusy enough‚Äù, also, my prices are very fair, figuring in Fiverr‚Äôs cut and all (and buyers who know what they are doing, or Google a bit to see what realistic prices and delivery times for quality work might be, should get to the same conclusion) so, no, I haven‚Äôt.
I also have many return and regular customers, and while some were affected due to the nature of their business, others weren‚Äôt, or even had more to do, that probably evened it out a bit.
My plan in case I‚Äôd have had more free time than I‚Äôd have liked for more than a month was actually not to lower my prices but to set up some new gigs and do more ‚Äúoffline‚Äù and with my own site.
I guess lowering one‚Äôs prices might work in a pinch but if they are already fair or even a bit (or much) lower than they should be, it can be problematic to rise them again when it becomes unsustainable.
In addition to that, I have to pay exactly the same for everything myself, partly even more (groceries have become more expensive), so lowering my own prices while my COL stays the same or is even higher, seems a bad idea, unless I‚Äôd not get enough orders as it is.
I‚Äôll be flexible if I have to, but for now, I‚Äôm happier with cutting down on my non-essential expenses, doing an order ot two less per week, and having more time for other things than work.

With this in mind, we are fully committed to supporting national health systems by engaging our expertise and assets to help mitigate and contain the COVID-19 pandemic, alongside continuing concerted efforts to eradicate polio.
Using the vast infrastructure developed to identify the poliovirus and deliver vaccination campaigns, the polio eradication program is pitching in to protect the vulnerable from COVID-19, especially in polio-endemic countries. thread_name: Since COVID-19 started I‚Äôm getting few jobs from the Spanish industry
thread_text:
Hi, how are you?, long time without posting.
I wanted to ask you about your experience since the coronavirus outbreak. I work with Spanish SEO and orders were drastically reduced, also impressions and clicks. I want to know if the Spanish industry was specially harmed or all marketing people worldwide are facing the same.
Thank you, kind regards.
reply_text:
I can‚Äôt comment on the Spanish CEO category, because that isn‚Äôt a service category that I am familiar with. However, I can say with certainty that there is a drastically increased level of competition on Fiverr, as a result of the global pandemic. More sellers, means existing sellers tend to see lower metrics from the search results. Perhaps there are too many people trying to sell services for your keywords, and your services aren‚Äôt being seen as much.
It‚Äôs also worth noting that, people just might not be searching for your services as much. The world is changing ‚Äì even moreso because of Covid. Perhaps there isn‚Äôt as much demand for your services now, compared to in the past.
Perhaps this might be a good time to start marketing and promoting your own services too, instead of relying on only the Fiverr search system to provide all your orders.

thread_name: Blessed by Fiverr in Covid-19 times
thread_text:
When I opened my Fiverr account last year, I had no clue that I would be greatly helped by this platform. I opened my account with curiosity and with the idea to explore. I had my graphics business well set in local market that time and I was doing good.
Slowly and steadily my account was developed on Fiverr and I was giving my time and energy on Fiverr but still my main work and especially revenue was getting generated in local market work.
But then Covid pandemic broke and in India, we have been to longest lock-down. Suddenly there was fear in the market. People around in our area started to consider graphics as the luxury thing and it was not considered essential, so I stopped receiving work from the local market. It was the time when starvation was knocking my door along with the frightening health situation around. Thankfully to Fiverr, I could keep getting my living on the platform. Now, I have started to focus more and more on Fiverr (gave Fiverr tests, added gigs,etc)
I have also decided that Fiverr will be my top priority even after the situation is normalized (though I don‚Äôt know when that will happen). I don‚Äôt think that my any words will be able to express my gratitude to the platform and to the buyers of my service. Truly obliged.
reply_text: Stay blessed. Stay with fiverr

thread_name: Is Corona Virus Pandemic affecting orders in fiverr?
thread_text:
Hey,
I used to get 10+ orders a month. Everything was going so well but suddenly in end of May I stopped getting orders like I used to get. last month I got only one order.
Is Corona Virus Pandemic really directly or indirectly affecting Orders?
reply_text:
makeyourlogoo:
Is Corona Virus Pandemic really directly or indirectly affecting Orders?
There are many reasons why your sales levels could rise or fall. Let‚Äôs not get into the habit of conveniently blaming the Covid pandemic for everything. I‚Äôve been seeing a lot of sellers doing this lately. Perhaps your competitors are doing a better job winning over your potential clients. Maybe there just isn‚Äôt as much demand for your services, or perhaps your service offering has grown a bit stale, and needs to be updated. Maybe your gig has entered rotation in the search results, and isn‚Äôt being seen by as many people as before. Are you doing any self-marketing? Are you doing anything on your own to connect to your target customers?
If things aren‚Äôt going as well as they once were, perhaps there are things that YOU can do to turn things back around. Trying to find something else to blame for the low sales isn‚Äôt a productive way to improve your success.
